title: Morning at The Daily Grind
description: You've stopped at your favorite coffee shop before an important meeting. You need to check a few things online, but which network should you trust?

scenes.title: Welcome to The Daily Grind
scenes.description: You settle into a comfortable corner seat with your latte. Your laptop is open and you see several Wi-Fi networks available. You have 30 minutes before your meeting.

scenes.title: Choose a Network
scenes.description: Several networks appear on your screen. The coffee shop has a sign on the counter, but you can't quite read it from here.

networks.description: Coffee shop guest network - no password required

actions.label: Ask staff for the correct network
actions.description: Walk to the counter and confirm the official Wi-Fi name

scenes.title: Staff Confirmation
scenes.description: The barista confirms: 'Our official network is DailyGrind_Guest. The password is on your receipt!' They also mention they've seen some fake networks pop up recently.

scenes.title: Check Your Email
scenes.description: You're connected to the verified official network. Now you need to check your email for the meeting agenda.

task.title: Check Work Email
task.description: Open your email to review the meeting agenda that was sent this morning.
task.riskHint: Email accounts often contain sensitive information and password reset links.

actions.label: Enable VPN first, then check email

scenes.title: Network Trap Detected
scenes.description: You connected to what appeared to be the coffee shop's network...

consequence.title: Fake Network Trap
consequence.whatHappened: You connected to 'FREE_Daily_Grind_WiFi' - a fake network set up by an attacker. A convincing login page appeared asking for your email to 'access the internet.' Any credentials you entered were captured.
consequence.whyRisky: Attackers often create networks with names similar to legitimate ones (called 'evil twin' attacks). Open networks with enticing names like 'FREE' are major red flags. The fake captive portal harvested your login credentials.
consequence.saferAlternative: Always verify the exact network name with staff before connecting. Look for secured networks (with the lock icon) and be suspicious of networks that are open but claim to be from a business.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Evil twin attacks work by broadcasting a stronger signal than the legitimate network, causing devices to connect automatically. The attacker then intercepts all traffic or presents fake login pages.

cascadingEffects.effect: Your email credentials were captured by the fake login page
Attacker uses your email to reset passwords on other accounts
Your linked bank and shopping accounts are now accessible
Personal data from these accounts enables identity theft

scenes.title: Connected to Open Network
scenes.description: You connected to the coffee shop's open guest network...

consequence.title: Unencrypted Connection
consequence.whatHappened: You connected to 'DailyGrind_Open' - the coffee shop's legitimate open network. While this is a real network, it has no password protection, meaning your traffic isn't encrypted at the network level.
consequence.whyRisky: Even legitimate open networks don't encrypt your traffic. Anyone on the same network can potentially see your browsing activity and any data sent over non-HTTPS connections. It's like having a conversation in a crowded room.
consequence.saferAlternative: The secured 'DailyGrind_Guest' network with WPA2 encryption is a better choice. It encrypts your traffic at the network level. When using any public network, enable a VPN for maximum protection.
consequence.technicalExplanation: WPA2 encryption scrambles data between your device and the router. Open networks transmit everything in plain text. While HTTPS protects individual website connections, network-level encryption adds another security layer.

scenes.title: Wrong Network
scenes.description: You connected to a neighboring business's network...

consequence.title: Unintended Network
consequence.whatHappened: You connected to the bookstore next door's network. While not malicious, you're now on a network you didn't intend to use, and your traffic is going through their router.
consequence.whyRisky: Even legitimate networks from other businesses route your traffic through equipment you don't control. The network administrator could potentially monitor traffic, and you have no agreement with them about data handling.
consequence.saferAlternative: Take a moment to verify you're connecting to the intended network. If you're at a coffee shop, connect to the coffee shop's official network, not a neighboring business.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Network administrators can log connection data and potentially inspect unencrypted traffic. Using the wrong network also means you're subject to their security practices (or lack thereof).

scenes.title: Email Checked
scenes.description: You checked your email on the verified network...

consequence.title: Reasonably Safe
consequence.whatHappened: You checked your email on the verified official network. Since your email provider uses HTTPS, your login credentials and email content were encrypted.
consequence.whyRisky: Even on legitimate networks, there's some risk. The network owner could potentially see that you're accessing your email service (metadata), even if they can't read the content.
consequence.saferAlternative: For extra security, especially on any public network, use a VPN. This encrypts all your traffic and hides even the metadata about which services you're using.
consequence.technicalExplanation: HTTPS encrypts the data between your browser and the email server, but DNS queries and connection metadata may still be visible to network observers.

scenes.title: VPN Protected
scenes.description: You enabled your VPN before checking email...

consequence.title: Excellent Security Practice
consequence.whatHappened: You enabled your VPN before accessing your email. All your traffic is now encrypted and routed through a secure tunnel, invisible to anyone on the coffee shop network.
consequence.whyRisky: VPN usage on public Wi-Fi is a best practice. The only minor consideration is that you're trusting your VPN provider, so choose a reputable one.
consequence.saferAlternative: You made the optimal choice! For maximum security, ensure your VPN is from a trusted provider with a no-logs policy.
consequence.technicalExplanation: A VPN creates an encrypted tunnel between your device and the VPN server. All traffic appears as encrypted data to the local network, and your real IP address is hidden from websites.

scenes.title: Task Postponed
scenes.description: You decided to wait on checking email...

consequence.title: Cautious Approach
consequence.whatHappened: You decided to postpone checking your email until you're on a more secure network. While perhaps overly cautious for just checking email, this eliminates any risk.
consequence.whyRisky: This was a very safe choice. The trade-off is convenience - you'll need to check email later when you have a more secure connection.
consequence.saferAlternative: For routine email checking on a verified network with HTTPS, proceeding with a VPN is a good balance of security and convenience.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Postponing eliminates all network-based risks. For time-sensitive but non-critical tasks, using a VPN on the verified network is a reasonable compromise.

scenes.title: Banking on Public Wi-Fi
scenes.description: You accessed your bank account on the public network...

consequence.title: High-Risk Banking
consequence.whatHappened: You logged into your bank on a public Wi-Fi network without VPN protection. While the bank uses HTTPS, this is still risky behavior that could expose you to sophisticated attacks.
consequence.whyRisky: Public networks can be compromised in ways that intercept even HTTPS traffic (SSL stripping, certificate spoofing on misconfigured devices). Banking credentials are among the most valuable targets for attackers.
consequence.saferAlternative: Never access banking on public Wi-Fi without a VPN. Better yet, postpone banking until you're on a trusted private network. If urgent, use your mobile data instead of public Wi-Fi.
consequence.technicalExplanation: While modern HTTPS is secure, attackers on the same network could attempt downgrade attacks, DNS spoofing to fake bank sites, or exploit any misconfigurations in your browser's certificate validation.

cascadingEffects.effect: Your banking session may be intercepted on the public network
Attacker captures your login credentials or session token
Unauthorized transfers drain your account before you notice

scenes.title: Protected Banking
scenes.description: You accessed your bank with VPN protection...

consequence.title: Smart Security Choice
consequence.whatHappened: You used a VPN before accessing your bank account. This adds a strong layer of encryption and prevents local network attacks from intercepting your traffic.
consequence.whyRisky: Using a VPN for banking on public Wi-Fi is a good practice. The remaining risk is minimal - mainly trusting your VPN provider and ensuring you're on the real bank website.
consequence.saferAlternative: For the most sensitive transactions, consider using your mobile data instead of any public Wi-Fi, even with a VPN. But your choice was a solid security decision.
consequence.technicalExplanation: The VPN encrypts all traffic before it leaves your device, making it impossible for local network attackers to intercept or manipulate your bank connection.

scenes.title: Banking Postponed
scenes.description: You decided to wait on banking...

consequence.title: Excellent Judgment
consequence.whatHappened: You recognized that banking is a high-sensitivity task and chose to postpone it until you're on a trusted network. This is exactly the right instinct.
consequence.whyRisky: This was the ideal choice. There's no risk because you didn't expose your banking credentials on a public network.
consequence.saferAlternative: You made the best possible decision. Banking should be reserved for trusted networks - your home Wi-Fi or mobile data connection.
consequence.technicalExplanation: By postponing high-sensitivity tasks, you eliminate the attack surface entirely. This 'security by avoidance' is often the most effective approach for critical operations.

scenes.description: You've completed the Coffee Shop Challenge! Let's review how you did.
